questions.stem: What should attendance notes include about the private consultation?

options.text: Only the outcome of the interview
Key times, instructions received, advice given, strategy agreed, and the client's decision
Just the client's name and date
Police opinions about the case

questions.explanation: Good consultation notes capture the essential elements: what was discussed, what was advised, and what the client decided.

questions.stem: What makes a reflection suitable for portfolio evidence?

options.text: Length — the longer the better
Demonstrating analysis, learning points, and specific actions for improvement
Blaming others for problems
Copying standard templates without personal analysis

questions.explanation: Quality reflections show genuine analysis and learning, not just description. They identify specific improvements.

references.cite: SRA PSRAS Assessment Guidelines — reflective practice

questions.stem: When should attendance notes be written?

options.text: Several days later when you have time
Contemporaneously or as soon as practicable after the events
Only if something goes wrong
At the end of the week

questions.explanation: Contemporaneous notes are more reliable and valuable. Write notes during or immediately after events while details are fresh.

questions.stem: What is the purpose of reflective practice in professional development?

options.text: To prove you made no mistakes
To learn from experience and continuously improve skills and practice
To blame colleagues
To avoid work

questions.explanation: Reflective practice is about learning and improvement. It helps identify what works, what doesn't, and how to do better next time.

references.cite: SRA PSRAS Assessment Guidelines — CPD and reflection

questions.stem: How should you handle errors in attendance notes?

options.text: Erase them completely
Strike through with a single line so the original is still visible, then add the correction with date/initials
Rewrite the entire document
Delete the file and start again

questions.explanation: Corrections should be transparent. Strike through (don't obliterate), add the correction, and initial/date it to maintain record integrity.

references.cite: Record keeping: corrections and amendments (Check: guidance)

questions.stem: Which reflection structure is most effective?

options.text: Random thoughts with no structure
Description of what happened, analysis of what went well/poorly, and what you would do differently
Just describing what police did
Copying the custody record

questions.explanation: Structured reflection (What? So what? Now what?) ensures you move beyond description to analysis and actionable learning.

references.cite: SRA PSRAS Assessment Guidelines — structured reflection

questions.stem: What level of detail is appropriate in attendance notes for police station work?

options.text: Minimal — just the date and outcome
Sufficient to reconstruct the key events, advice, instructions, and decisions later
Every word spoken by everyone
Only information requested by police

questions.explanation: Notes should be detailed enough to allow reconstruction of key elements but focused on what matters professionally and legally.

questions.stem: How does reflective practice support accreditation assessment?

options.text: It doesn't — only the written exam matters
It demonstrates developing competence, insight, and commitment to improvement
It proves you never made mistakes
It replaces practical experience

questions.explanation: Assessors look for evidence of developing competence. Reflection demonstrates insight, learning, and professional growth.

references.cite: SRA PSRAS Assessment Guidelines — portfolio evidence
